adjective.description: Designating an English translation of the New Testament made by Roman Catholics of the English College at Rheims in 1582, based closely on the Vulgate text.

origin: Late 16th century; earliest use found in John Rainolds (1549–1607), theologian and college head. From Rhemes, earlier English form of Rheims, the name of a city in the north-east of France, where the translation was made and published + -ish.
